BOOK IT. r i i l i ii I. rORTUNE was already preparing, in book another quarter of the world, to open an important scene, and to. produce to mankind a new imperial family, destined, at first (a), to flourish in prosperity, and, in the end, after a disastrous reign, to fall by a dreadful catastrophe. While Galba still possessed the sovereign power, Titus, by order of Vespasian, his father, set out from Judaea, with congratulations to that emperor, and, as was natural, with the ambition of a young man eager to begin the career (b) of public honours.
